poem:
**On the Edge of a Page**

Words spill like ink onto the churning sea—  
the author stands on cliffs of debate.  
A title turns tempest, quills clash,  
binding lines to fragile sheets of self.  
Yet in this gale of fierce voices,  
truth bends but doesn't break,  
carried by the whisper of turning pages—  
a narrative, braving its own storm.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "John Boyne says LGBTQ+ fiction prize backlash brought him ‘close to the edge’ The gender-critical Irish novelist John Boyne has said he has been brought “very close to the edge” by the backlash to his inclusion on the longlist for a literary prize for LGBTQ+ authors. Ten authors and two judges withdrew from the Polari prize and more than 800 writers and publishing industry workers signed a petition calling on Polari to remove Boyne’s novella". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
